bibl.title: Letter from Jesse T. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 25, 1901

div1.p: Jesse T. Lazear provides family news. He reports that two noted physicians spoke to him about Jesse W. Lazear's death.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse T. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, August 25, 1901
div1.opener:
Hotel Acadia I. C. HALL, Proprietor
GRAND TRACADIE BEACH
PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND
Aug 25 1901
My dear Aunt
div1.p:
Shortly after my return from
Baltimore I commissioned Chris. to write
you to express my appreciation of my
visit and that I would write you
myself in a few days. Although two
months have past I have come to
the conclusion, that better late than
never, I might avail myself of
the leisure this place affords me.
For the first time the entirely family
from father to John are under
one roof for some-weeks, and while
the crowded condition of the house
prevents the family reunion to the
some extent, yet father collects the
the boys around him for instruction &
for fishing, neither of which seem to be
successful. Poor father, had extolled the
beauties of this place all the years that
when things - do not go well he feels the
responsibility of a landlord and has
an explanation for every defect. On
the whole we are delighted with the
place, principally as the air is so
pure & the location healthful, as a
nerve restorer it is about the best,
as there is nothing exciting; ever the appear-
ance of a white starched shirt creates
comment. In front of the hotel thousand
of wild ducks & geese can be seen floating
in the bay, but no one seems able
to devise a plan to get within gunshot.
Father contracted a severe cold before
leaving home and is having his
trouble in getting over it, as so many
remedies have been suggested. which
he can not adopt as the supply of
patent medicine on the Island is
very limited. Mother is some what
relieved of her asthma, but I fear
it has become so chronic that she
will never be entirely free of it.
I have no doubt Thomas has been
supply the house with fish all summer,
tell him one of the guests brought in
a three found brook trout which
was a beauty but required a day's labor
Hotel Acadia I. C. HALL, Proprietor
GRAND TRACADIE BEACH
PRINCE EDWARD ISLAND
1901
and an expenditure of above $20. Ann
and her brood leave next week
for home greatly benefitted in body &
mind. Ann is as brown as an indian
and her nerves are as composed as in
anti-twine days. All the children are being
spoiled by the hotel guests. It makes>
me feel old to sell Alice & Jane waltzing
No “two-stepping” with young fellows every
night. Two noted physicians from Boston
have been at the hotel and interested us
in expressing their views of the noble sacri-
fice Jesse made. Dr Bowes says that
at the annual meeting of the Massachusetts
medical society President Eelloit of
Harvard addressed the society and this
theme was the martyrdom of Dr Jesse
W. Lazear. Dr Bowes says he believes the
AC
L
medical profession will some day erect a
a monument to him at Havana, and that
in his children's life time he will be
known as one of the greatest scientists
of the Country. I hope Frances has enjoyed
her vacation and is prepared for the
winter's work. We are looking foreward
to the pleasure of having you with us
this fall, and I know Chris can enter-
tain, for she believes in making the
relatives feel at home.
